dt: {bc}relating to grain or to the plants that produce it

et: borrowed from French & Latin; French {it}céréale,{/it} borrowed from Latin {it}Ceriālis, Cereālis{/it} "of the goddess Ceres, of wheat or bread," from {it}Cerer-, Cerēs{/it} {et_link|ceres|Ceres} + {it}-ālis{/it} {et_link|-al:1|-al:1}

The derivation of {it}Ceriālis, Cereālis{/it} is unclear, as formation directly from the noun does not look possible. M. Leumann ({it}Lateinische Laut- und Formenlehre,{/it} Munich, 1977, p. 180) suggests as the base an earlier {it}*Cerrius,{/it} from {it}*Cerzios,{/it} syncopated from a possessive adjective {it}*Cerez-ios.{/it} A putative {it}*Cerriālis{/it} would have been re-formed to {it}Ceriālis,{/it} then {it}Cereālis,{/it} after {it}Cerēs.{/it}
shortdef: relating to grain or to the plants that produce it; also : made of grain

dt: {bc}a plant (such as a grass) yielding starchy grain suitable for food
{bc}a prepared foodstuff of grain (such as oatmeal or cornflakes)

shortdef: a plant (such as a grass) yielding starchy grain suitable for food; also : its grain
a prepared foodstuff of grain (such as oatmeal or cornflakes)

dt: {bc}a small reddish-brown black-headed Old World chrysomelid beetle ({it}Oulema melanopus{/it}) that feeds on cereal grasses and is a serious pest of U.S. grain crops

shortdef: a small reddish-brown black-headed Old World chrysomelid beetle (Oulema melanopus) that feeds on cereal grasses and is a serious pest of U.S. grain crops
